content.description:
This fun easy problem climbs an obvious flared corner system via highsteps to a delicate mantle finish.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Southwest corner of the boulder and just left of

Downtime

.

content.description:
SDS at the blunt arete with a left hand edge and right hand pinch and power up to a tricky highstep and then finish up fun face past horizontal slashes. Can be done from a standing start at V0-.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Left side of the west face at a rounded arete and just left of

Kiss of Fire

.

content.description:
Starting from a flake embedded in the ground climb the nice slab past jugs and edges. This is also the best downclimb for the boulder.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.

SDS at a flat shelf and sidepull and make a reach to a couple of high edges/pinches over a small roof and then up past better holds to an easy topout. The landing on this isn't the best with careful padding it can be made decent.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: Right side of the north face.

content.description:
SDS at a slanting rail, reach left to a flat edge/sidepull and make technical moves getting stood up to gain a distant edge. Easier moves lead to a large flake and an easy topout. Can be done from a standing start at V-easy.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Left side of the west face between

Ring of Fire

and

Brownout

.

content.description: Work up thin, slick edges to an undercut horizontal crack then traverse right and up past a shelf or go big for the top. Tricky for the grade.
content.protection: Several pads to level out the sloping landing, spotter
content.location: Right side of the south face.

content.description:
Starting from a high flat hold work your feet up over the lip of an undercut roof to positive holds higher and a juggy topout.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Center of the east face between

Finger Food

and

Raw Heat

.

content.description:
Starting from the ground climb up and into an undercut thin crack, getting jams where possible, to a committing reach into the final slot where the crack opens up. Easier moves lead from there to the top.

The landing zone on this looks fairly bad but with careful padding it's actually pretty safe.
content.protection: 2-3 pads to cover and fill in the rocky landing and several spotters are nice.
content.location: Left side of the east face.

content.description: Balance up the smooth vertical face to gain a short crack that ends with a jug and a bush.
content.location:
Left side of the south face and left of

Habanero

.

content.description:
Featured face past incut edges, patina rails and jugs galore on this problem which has not the best of landings.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Right side of the east face and just right of

Raw Heat

.

content.description:
Interesting climbing past diagonal slashes to a rounded topout with hidden holds.

This problem isn't listed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location: Right side of the west face.

content.description: Climb smooth vertical face past occasional diagonal slashes to reach a large flake and the end of the difficulties. Can be done from a sit start at about V1 or so.
content.location: Center of the west face and just left of a small yucca at the base.
